subject: RE: [junit] fail message problem.
msgSnippet: I would start by looking at the code in dbObject.getConnected().  That method is not producing an Exception so there s nothing to catch.  Maybe that method
messageBody:
I would start by looking at the code in dbObject.getConnected(). That
method is not producing an Exception so there's nothing to catch. Maybe
that method *handles* the exception thrown when the database is down.
Alternatively it might throw a RuntimeException, which you would need to
catch using RuntimeException (or Throwable) instead of Exception.

regards, APC


-----Original Message-----
From: Bhavaniprasad Polimetla
[mailto:bhavaniprasad.polimetla@...]
Sent: 15 May 2001 13:07
To: junit
Subject: [junit] fail message problem.


dear sir,

Database is down.
i am expecting the first fail message in the following code.
but the system is giving second fail message. why?

thankyou,
Bhavani.

/*****^^^^^*****^^^^^***** Test Case 5 *****^^^^^*****^^^^^*****/
//public ResultSet getResult(Connection connObj, String stQuery, Vector
vParams)
public void testgetResult1()
{
String msg = "Test case 5 - ResultSet getResult(Connection connObj,
String stQuery, Vector vParams) - passing all correct parameters";
System.out.println("\n"+msg);
Connection connObj1 = null;
try{
connObj1 = dbObject.getConnected();
}
catch(Exception ex){
fail(msg + "- getConnected() - exception->"+ex.getMessage());
}

ResultSet rs1 = null;
Vector vParams1 = new Vector();
try{
rs1 = dbObject.getResult(connObj1,"select count(*) from
tab",vParams1);
while (rs1.next()){
int iTable_count = rs1.getInt(1);
if(51 != iTable_count)
fail(msg + "- wrong returned values");
}
rs1.close();
}
catch(Exception ex){
fail(msg + "- exception->"+ex.getMessage());
}
dbObject = null;

}
